bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 31, [1902]

div1.p: Reed asks for news of Keewaydin. He and Kean continue the campaign for Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 31, [1902]
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
May 31-
8.30 P.M.
My precious wifie,
div1.p:
If I can
keep awake long enough,
I want to write two or
three lines; but sleepy?
Oh! dear me! don't mention
it! I wander if Keeway-
din's occupants have
already sought their
Couches? Or did you get
a short nap at your
accustomed hour this
afternoon- I watched
the clock and when noon
came, I wondered if you
had not reached the
house and allowed poor
Mr Complaining Doogy
to escape from his
prison- I know that
he enjoyed his release.
Did he seem to recog-
nize anything about the
place? I am sure that
he did- Do pray tell me
whether my tomato plants
are all dead or not-
and what has been ac-
complished during the
week by Methren, Moore
& Co- Do things look green?
It looks tonight as if it
would rain- I had my
first meal with Miss
Mason to-night and enjoyed
her Cook's seasoning very
much for a change- The
only thing I missed was
Dugdale's soup- By the way,
Dr Kean came down to
see me, this afternoon- He
looks splendidly and is Chuck
full of fight for the Surgeon
Generalcy- Has declared
war on Dewitt- Thinks
that he would be the
last selection to be made
as a chief- We adjourned
to Hancock's & after a
a Mint-Julep, concluded
that we would start an
active campaign beginning
tomorrow. We are now
out for blood- B-L
O-O-D! Do you compre-
hend evous?

Good-night, Sweethearts,
Papa is so sleepy- Love
to Mrs. Stewart- Love
& kisses for my precious
children- Write very
often-
